question: Different mutations in the same genetic locus causing similar or identical phenotype is?
exp: Allelic heterogeneity Different mutations in the same genetic locus can cause an identical or similar phenotype. eg- different mutations of the b-globin locus- b-thalassemia Phenotypic Heterogeneity When more than one phenotype is caused by allelic mutations e. g. Identical mutations in the FGFR2 gene- Crouzon syndrome or Pfeiffer syndrome Locus or Non-allelic Heterogeneity Similar disease phenotype results from mutations at different genetic loci. eg- osteogenesis imperfecta- mutations in COL1. A1 or COL 1. A2: located on different chromosomes

question: In an autosomal Recessive (AR) disorder, one parent is normal and the other is carrier and the child is also affected. What is the reason?
exp: If one parent is normal for an autosomal recessive disorder and the other is carrier - No child should be affected. But there is exception to this rule, i. e. uniparental disomy (UPD), when a person receives 2 copies of a chromosome, from one parent and no copies from the other parent. Ex: In Prader-Willi syndrome- maternal UPD of chromosome 15 (missing the paternal chromosome 15). In Angelman syndrome- paternal UPD of chromosome 15 (missing the maternal chromosome 15).

question: Triple test includes all the following EXCEPT?
exp: Triple test includes: AFP HCG Estradiol Quadruple test: also include Inhibin All women are offered screening for Down syndrome in their 2nd trimester by means of 4 maternal serum tests (free b-human chorionic gonadotropin, unconjugated estriol, inhibin, and a-fetoprotein). This is known as the quad screen; it can detect up to 80% of Down syndrome pregnancies compared to 70% in the triple screen.

The law "Relative frequencies of each gene allele tends to remain constant from generation to generation", was given by:
exp: Hardy-Weinberg's law It describes a theoretical situation in which a population is undergoing no evolutionary change It explains that if the evolutionary forces are absent, the population is large and its individuals have random mating Thus each parent produces equal number of gametes Such gametes combine at random and the gene frequency remains constant. Finally the genetic equilibrium of the genes is maintained and the variability present in the population is preserved.

question: True statement about inheritance of an X-linked recessive trait is:
exp: For a X-linked recessive disease: If mother is a carrier: If father is diseased: 50% of boys of carrier mothers are affected All daughters are carriers Mothers transmit defective gene to 50% of the sons (diseased) as well as daughters (carriers) Fathers transmit defective gene to daughters
opa: 50% of boys of carrier mother are affected
opb: 50% of girls of diseased father are carrier
opc: Father transmits disease to the son
opd: Mother transmits the disease to the daughter

question: For karyotyping, the dividing cells are arrested by the addition of colchicine in which of the following mitotic phase?
exp: Chromosomes are examined after arresting dividing cells in metaphase with mitotic spindle inhibitors (e. g., N-diacetyl N-methylcolchicine), followed by staining.

question: Which of the following procedures is routine technique for karyotyping using light microscopy:

question: Which is the longest chromosome?
exp: Chromosome 1 is the longest chromosome. In a karyotype, chromosomes- arranged according to their length and banding features. Chromosomes 1 to 22 are arranged according to their length, in the descending order. Chromosome X is longer than the Y Chromosome.
